speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The brain regulates the body by anticipating its needs and attempting to meet them before they arise, a process called allostasis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Allostasis requires a model of the changing sensory conditions within the body, a process called interoception.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In this paper, we examine how interoception may provide performance feedback for allostasis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We suggest studying allostasis in terms of control theory, reviewing control theory's applications to related issues in physiology, motor control, and decision making.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We synthesize these by relating them to the important properties of allostatic regulation as a control problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We then sketch a novel formalism for how the brain might perform allostatic control.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: of the viscera by analogy to skeletal motor control, including a mathematical view on how interoception acts as a performance feedback for allostasis.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Finally, we suggest ways to test implications of our hypothesis.
